summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to the Assistant Attorney General requesting permission to call two witnesses at her trial: an FBI Special Agent involved in the 2006-2008 Florida investigation of Jeffrey Epstein, and a former Assistant U.S. Attorney who met with alleged victims' attorneys in 2016. The letter outlines the testimony sought to impeach a witness and to discuss the origins of the investigation.

persons.name: Kenneth A. Polite, Jr.
persons.context: Addressee of the letter from Maxwell's defense attorneys, responsible for the Criminal Division of the U.S. Department of Justice.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced, represented by the law firm sending the letter.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the investigations into sexual abuse; his actions and the Non-Prosecution Agreement are discussed as background to the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who signed the letter representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: Maxwell is on trial for allegations related to Epstein's sexual abuse scheme; the letter discusses investigations into both.
Everdell, as part of Cohen & Gresser LLP, is representing Maxwell in her criminal case.

events.title: Florida Investigation into Epstein
events.description: An investigation conducted by the Palm Beach FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida into allegations of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Witness Interview
events.description: An interview of a witness (who is expected to testify against Maxwell) conducted by an FBI Special Agent during the Florida Investigation.

events.title: Meeting with Victims' Attorneys
events.description: A meeting where attorneys for alleged victims met with a former AUSA to persuade the USAO-SDNY to open an investigation into Epstein and Maxwell, discussing the prior Florida NPA.

events.title: Miami Herald Article and Case Reopening
events.description: After a critical Miami Herald article about the Epstein NPA, the former AUSA approached prosecutors, leading the USAO-SDNY to open the investigation that resulted in Maxwell's indictment.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Testimony
events.description: The date for which the defense seeks to call the FBI Special Agent and former AUSA to testify at Maxwell's trial.

keyFacts: The defense seeks to call an FBI Special Agent from the 2006-2008 Florida Epstein investigation to impeach a witness whose trial testimony may conflict with her 2007 interview statements.
The defense also seeks to call a former Assistant U.S. Attorney who, in 2016, met with attorneys for alleged victims who urged a new investigation into Epstein and Maxwell.
The 2016 meeting did not immediately result in an investigation; it was a 2018 Miami Herald article that prompted the former AUSA to come forward, leading to the investigation that indicted Maxwell.
The letter reveals the defense's strategy to challenge the prosecution's narrative by questioning the origins and consistency of the investigation and witness accounts.
The document references a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) that resolved the earlier Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.
